title: How to Cook Carrots

steps.headline: Wash the carrots thoroughly.
steps.description: Before cooking the carrots, wash them thoroughly in the sink with cold water. Because carrots are a root vegetable, they will generally have some dirt residue on their skin. Therefore, you may need to use a paper towel or vegetable sponge to get them thoroughly cleaned. You can also purchase and use a vegetable wash to help remove more impurities.

steps.headline: Trim the stems and roots of the carrots.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to cut of the stems of the carrots. Then, slice off any stringy roots that may still be attached to the tips. If you’re roasting or grilling the carrots, you can leave the stems attached for a fancier presentation.

steps.headline: Peel the carrots if you prefer to remove the skin.
steps.description: If you plan to use your carrots in a dish, purée them, or prefer them peeled, you can use a sharp knife or potato peeler to remove the skin. Be careful, though, as carrots can be difficult to peel, particularly if they are thin and flimsy towards the root. If you like peeled carrots and want to save time, you can buy packed baby carrots that are already peeled at most grocery stores.

steps.headline: Chop the carrots if you want them to cook faster.
steps.description: Chop the carrots into several small slices will  make them soften and cook a bit faster. In addition, if you plan to serve the carrots chopped, slicing them up ahead of time will also save you time later. If you plan to serve the carrots whole, however, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Bring a pot of salted water to a boil.
steps.description: First, fill a pot about ½ to ¾ of the way up with water. Add about ½ teaspoon (2 grams) of salt per 1 litre (0.26 US gal) of water. Then, turn the stovetop on high to bring the water to a boil. Use enough water to cover the carrots but not so much that the water boils over the side when you add the carrots. Adding salt makes the carrots boil faster and adds a bit of flavor. If you’re watching your sodium intake, however, you can leave the salt out.

steps.headline: Add the carrots to the boiling water and cover the pot.
steps.description: Using your hands or tongs, place the carrots into the boiling water carefully so that the water doesn’t splash onto your skin. Once all the carrots are added, cover the pot with a lid and leave the carrots to boil.

steps.headline: Let the carrots boil for 4 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: The amount of time that the carrots will need to boil depends on how they were cut, as well as how tender you’d like them to be. If you chopped the carrots into small slices, for example, you can let them boil for about 4 minutes if you like them to be softened on the outside and a bit crisp on the inside. If you prefer your carrots more tender all the way through, boil them for about 10 minutes. If you’re cooking full carrots that are thicker and unpeeled, you may need to boil them for up to 30 minutes if you want them to fully softened all the way through.

steps.headline: Cut a small piece off a carrot to see if they’re cooked.
steps.description: To test if the carrots are cooked to your liking at any point, you can remove one carrot from the pot and cut a small piece off before putting the rest back in. Let the small piece cool for a few seconds, then taste it to see if the carrots are done.

steps.headline: Drain the water and season the carrots to your taste.
steps.description: Once the carrots are cooked to your liking, turn off the stovetop. Place a colander in the sink and pour the carrots and water into it until all the water drains out the bottom. You can then place the carrots in a bowl or on a plate to season them according to your preference and serve. A simple salt and pepper seasoning is a great option for boiled carrots. If you like your carrots a bit sweeter, try seasoning with butter and a sprinkle of brown sugar.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C).
steps.description: Set the oven to preheat to 400 °F (204 °C). You can then cut and prepare the carrots while the oven is heating up.

steps.headline: Cut the carrots in half if they are over 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick.
steps.description: To get thick carrots to roast quicker and get a bit crispier, use a sharp knife to cut them in half lengthwise. If you prefer smaller pieces, you can also cut them diagonally into 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) slices. If the carrots are thinner, you can skip this step and leave them whole.

steps.headline: Toss the carrots in olive oil and seasoning.
steps.description: Place the carrots in a bowl or on a plate. Drizzle them with olive oil, starting with about 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of oil per 1 pound (0.45 kg) of carrots. Toss the carrots in the oil, adding a bit more oil as needed to coat. Then, sprinkle the carrots with salt, pepper, or any seasoning that you’d like to use. Toss the carrots again to spread the seasoning evenly. You can use melted butter or another type of cooking oil instead of olive oil if you prefer.

steps.headline: Spread the carrots out on a sheet pan.
steps.description: Try to spread the carrots out as much as possible. If you’re cooking a lot though, it’s okay if a few of them are touching. At this point, you can leave the carrots uncovered or cover them loosely with foil if you’d like them to get a bit more tender.

steps.headline: Roast the carrots in the oven for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Transfer the sheet pan with the carrots into the oven on the middle rack. Leave the carrots to roast in the oven for about 20 minutes. Once done, the carrots should appear brown and tender when pressed with a fork. If you like your carrots a bit crispier, cook them in the oven uncovered for another 5 minutes or so.

steps.headline: Garnish the carrots with herbs or any additional seasonings.
steps.description: Once the carrots are cooked to your liking, remove them from the oven. Toss them immediately with dill, parsley, or any herbs or seasonings that you prefer before serving. Try sprinkling your roasted carrots with garlic, sea salt, and a drizzle of honey for a unique, restaurant worthy side dish.

steps.headline: Try a steamer basket for a traditional steaming method.
steps.description: Fill the bottom 1 inch (2.5 cm) of a saucepan with water. Turn the stovetop on high to bring the water to a boil. Place the carrots in a steamer basket and put the basket in the middle of the saucepan. Cover the basket and saucepan with a lid, leaving a small gap on the sides to let the steam vent. Let the carrots steam for 5 to 10 minutes, depending on how tender you prefer them to be. Once the carrots are cooked to your liking, lift the basket above the saucepan and hold it for a few seconds to let the excess water drip off the carrots. Transfer the carrots into a bowl or onto a plate, season as you like, and serve.

steps.headline: Steam the carrots in a frying pan if you don’t have a basket.
steps.description: Add 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water to a frying pan. Turn the stovetop on high to bring to the water to a boil. Place the carrots in the boiling water carefully, then cover them with a lid. Leave the carrots to steam for 5 to 10 minutes until the water has completely evaporated. Once the water is evaporated, the carrots are done. You can then toss them with the seasoning of your choice and serve them immediately.

steps.headline: Use a bowl to steam carrots in the microwave.
steps.description: Place the carrots in a microwave-safe bowl. Add about 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of water to the bowl, then cover it with a lid or plate. Microwave the carrots on high for about 4 minutes, adding a minute or 2 as needed until the carrots reach your desired tenderness. If there is any excess water, you can pour the carrots into a colander to drain.

steps.headline: Heat 1.5 tablespoons (22 mL) of oil in a pan.
steps.description: Place a large pan on the stovetop and add 1.5 tablespoons (22 mL) of the oil of your choice. Then, turn the stovetop on low heat to gradually heat up the oil. Olive oil, avocado oil, and sunflower oil are all great options for sautéing carrots.

steps.headline: Cook the carrots with the lid on for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Transfer the carrots carefully into the pan, then cover it with the lid. While you want to leave the lid on most of the time, remove it occasionally to stir the carrots, about once every minute and a half or so. This will help ensure that the carrots cook evenly.

steps.headline: Uncover the pan and cook the carrots for another 8 minutes.
steps.description: Remove the lid from the pan and place it off to the side on a heat-safe surface. Then, raise the heat on the stovetop to medium. Let the carrots cook for another 8 minutes, stirring them almost constantly.

steps.headline: Remove the carrots from the stovetop and add a seasoning.
steps.description: Once the carrots are tender and are starting to brown, remove them from the stovetop and transfer them onto a plate or into a bowl. Then, sprinkle the carrots with the seasoning of your choice before serving them plain or using them in a dish. Try adding a simple salt and pepper seasoning along with some fresh herbs, such as dill, parsley, or sage, to your sautéed carrots.

steps.headline: Heat your grill to about 300 °F (149 °C).
steps.description: If you have an electric grill, turn the grill on and set the temperature to 300 °F (149 °C). If you have a charcoal grill, light the grill and check the thermostat until it heats up to about 300 °F (149 °C). If your charcoal grill doesn’t have a thermostat, heat it to a low to medium heat level. The flames should be relatively low.

steps.headline: Toss the carrots in olive oil and salt.
steps.description: While your grill is heating up, place the cleaned carrots on a plate and drizzle them with olive oil. Toss the carrots to coat. Then, add a pinch of salt and any other seasonings you like to taste.

steps.headline: Transfer the carrots onto the grill.
steps.description: Place the carrots directly on the grill grates and spread them apart so that none are touching. Then, close the grill to let the carrots begin to cook.

steps.headline: Let the carrots cook for about 20 minutes.
steps.description: Rotate them with tongs every 5 minutes or so to prevent them from burning. While the carrots are grilling, you can brush them occasionally with a balsamic glaze. By brushing it on while the carrots are still on the grill, the glaze will caramelize a bit, giving the carrots a sweeter flavor.

steps.headline: Remove the carrots from the grill and season them as desired.
steps.description: Once the carrots are tender and crisp, use tongs to transfer them from the grill into a plate. Add your choice of seasoning, then serve while hot. You can also add a glaze after removing the carrots from the grill.
